title: Are punitive damages allowed under federal debt collection laws?
question: There is a debt collector I'm considering suing for their harassment and calling my relatives. I've read some different stuff on the internet, so i thought I'd come to the professionals.
answers:
The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) does not allow for punitive damages.

But your state law may have a provision that allows for punitive damages against debt collectors who violate the law.

In Alabama, where I practice, we have a number of state law torts that in the right circumstances allow for punitive damages. The most common tort in a debt collection context is "Invasion of Privacy" but depending on what you are dealing with there may be others.

As the others have suggested, get with a good consumer lawyer in California and find out your rights.

Best of success to you....

John Watts
Birmingham, Alabama

"Punitive damages" are not included in the FDCPA. You can recover "actual damages", which may include emotional distress and aggravation and annoyance. You can also recover between $100 and $1,000. per violation, under the FDCPA. In addition, you can recover an additional $100. to $1,000. under California's Rosenthal Act. More importantly, you can also recover attorney's fees. There was a case ("Komarova") that went to jury trial in San Francisco about 2 years ago in which the jury awarded $340,000. in compensatory damages, $240,000. in attorney's fees, court costs of about $20,000. and punitive damages of $75,000. This judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeal. You should have a consultation with an attorney with litigation experience in this area. The viability of a lawsuit against the collection agency will depend upon a number of factors not contained in your question.

Simply put - NO.

The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act permits $1000 in statutory damages, above the amount of actual damages and attorney's fees, pursuant to 15 U.S.C. Section 1692k(a). You should get competent counsel for your case, as there are technical ways to get a case dismissed. You could also end up having your case removed to U.S. District Court, even if you filed it in small claims. I have seen that done and it can be a nightmare scenario for the self-represented plaintiff.
